text:
Stephan's Method

I multiplied the cycle lengths to find the next time the cicadas will appear together.
Does Stephan's method work for any pair of cycles? If so, explain why. If not, provide an example for which Stephan's method does not work.

Stephan's method works only for cycle lengths that do not have ant common factors other than 1. If the two cycle lengths have a common factor other than 1, then they will occur at the same time sooner than if you just multiplied the cycle lengths together. For example, for cycle lengths of 4 and 6, they first share a multiple after 4 ⋅ 3 = 12 = 6 ⋅ 2 years and not after 4 ⋅ 6 = 24 years.

Situation B. More Cicadas

Suppose there are 12-year, 14- year, and 16- year cicadas that all appear this year. After how many years will all three cicadas appear together again? Explain.

One type will appear every 12 years, another typr will appear every 14 years, and the last type will appear every 16 years. The three types of cicadas will appear together again after a number of years that is a multiple of 12, 14, and 16.

The least common multiple of 12, 14, and 16 is 336. After 336 years, all three cicadas will appear the same year. When listing the multiples of each (students may do this using three calculators, the first time they will match is at 336 years.

Some students will realize that these numbers share the factor of 2. Using this idea, they may think of the numbers as (6 ⋅ 2), (7 ⋅ 2), and (8 ⋅ 2). They then "ignore the 2" and multiple the 6 ⋅ 7 ⋅ 8, because that product will be a multiple of 12, 14, and 16.

(Note that this strategy works because the 8 has a factor of 2. Otherwise, using this strategy, they may have to multiply the "ignored number" into the product.)

Situation C. Hank Adds New Cards

Hank added ore cards to his Algebra Connections game. N is a whole number.

What answers would Hank write on the back of each card?

Students are likely to list the multiples of each number and look for multiples in common,

Some students will realize that they can find the multiples of the larger number. They then check to find the first one that is also a multiple of the second number.

Some students may use the relationships of the factors that the numbers share. like those looked at with the Ferris wheels in Problem 2.1 What If...? Situation A.

30

Multiples of 30: 30, 60, etc.

Multiples of 5: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, etc.

Because 5 is a factor of 30, the first multiple they share will be 30

60

Multiples of 20: 20, 40, 60, 80, etc.

Multiples of 12: 12, 24, 36, 48, 60, etc.

The numbers have the factor 4 in common, so the LCM will not be one of the numbers or the product of the two numbers.

143

Multiples of 13:

13, 26, 39, 52, 65, 78, 91, 104, 117, 130, 143, etc.

The numbers do not share any factors; they are relatively prime. So the LCM is the product of the two numbers.
